content:
The Sterling Forest and New Jersey Watershed Protection Act of 1993 allows for land acquisition. The Palisades Park Commission is authorized to acquire an open space tract of land from the Sterling Forest Corporation in the Sterling Forest area of the New York/New Jersey Highlands Region. The Commission shall manage the acquired land to enhance it. The New Jersey Highlands Region Management Commission shall manage the acquired land to enhance protection of watershed, outdoor recreational, wildlife habitat, and Appalachian Trail values in the Sterling Forest area of the New York/New Jersey Highlands Region. The New Jersey Highlands Region Management Commission is authorized for appropriations. The Secretary of the Interior is authorized to appropriate $35,000,000 for acquiring land described in section 2. Funds made available shall be transferred to the Commission as necessary to carry out this Act. The Act may be cited as the "Sterling Forest Protection Act of 1994". The Palisades Interstate Park Commission manages 23 parks and historic sites in New York and New Jersey, totaling over 82,000 acres. It receives over 8 million visitors annually for outdoor recreational opportunities. Sterling Forest is a biologically diverse open space on the New Jersey border, comprising approximately 17,500 acres. It serves as a significant watershed area for the State of New Jersey, providing clean drinking water for 25 percent of the state. Additionally, Sterling Forest is an important outdoor recreational asset in the northeastern United States. Sterling Forest in New Jersey provides clean drinking water for 25% of the state and supports a diverse ecosystem with 27 rare or endangered species. It is strategically located on a wildlife migratory route and enhances the Appalachian National Scenic Trail. The protection of Sterling Forest is crucial as it supports 27 rare or endangered species and enhances the Appalachian National Scenic Trail. Stewardship costs for the Palisades Park System are covered by New York and New Jersey. The protection of Sterling Forest is important due to its rare species and support for the Appalachian Trail. Stewardship costs for the Palisades Park System are covered by New York and New Jersey, minimizing the need for Federal funds. The Federal interest in acquiring Sterling Forest is driven by its significant watershed, recreational, and wildlife qualities, as well as the high demand for open space in the densely populated Tri-State region. Acquiring Sterling Forest for permanent protection is a cost-effective investment compared to the costs of protecting drinking water for the region if the forest is developed. The purposes of acquiring Sterling Forest are outlined in Section 3. The Sterling Forest Reserve in New York is established to protect watershed, wildlife, and recreational resources. Federal funding is authorized for acquisition costs, the Palisades Interstate Park Commission will convey certain lands to the Secretary of the Interior, and management of the Reserve is provided for. The Sterling Forest Reserve in New York is established to protect watershed, wildlife, and recreational resources. Federal funding is authorized for acquisition costs, and the Palisades Interstate Park Commission will convey certain lands to the Secretary of the Interior for management of the Reserve. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS.

The term "Commission" refers to the Palisades Interstate Park Commission, "Reserve" means the Sterling Forest Reserve, and "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior.

SEC. 5. ESTABLISHMENT OF THE STERLING FOREST RESERVE. The Sterling Forest Reserve in New York is established by the Commission upon acquiring sufficient lands. The Reserve consists of approximately 17,500 acres as depicted on a map available for public inspection. The Commission establishes the Sterling Forest Reserve in New York with approximately 17,500 acres of lands depicted on a map available for public inspection. The Secretary will transfer funds for land acquisition within the Reserve, subject to specified conditions. The Commission establishes the Sterling Forest Reserve in New York with approximately 17,500 acres of lands available for public inspection. Prior to receiving Federal funds, the Commission must agree to conditions including managing lands in accordance with the Act and conveying fee title to the United States if not compliant. No lands can be acquired with Federal funds if not authorized by the Act. The Commission must agree to conditions including conveying fee title to the United States at the time of purchase. Lands cannot be acquired with Federal funds without owner consent. If unable to acquire all lands, the Commission must acquire National Park Service Wilderness Easement Lands and Conservation Easement Lands using Federal funds. The Commission must acquire National Park Service Wilderness Easement Lands and Conservation Easement Lands before acquiring any other lands within the Reserve, and convey them to the United States within 30 days. The Commission must convey conservation easements on National Park Service Wilderness Easement Lands and Conservation Easement Lands to the United States to protect their wilderness character. Conservation easements on National Park Service Conservation Easement Lands must protect wilderness character and restrict development to align with the Appalachian National Scenic Trail's protection. Conservation easements on National Park Service Conservation Easement Lands must align with the Appalachian National Scenic Trail's protection and restrict development. Funds for development must be matched from non-Federal sources when transferred to the Commission. The Commission is responsible for managing lands within the Reserve in line with its authorities and the Act's purposes. Within 3 years, a general management plan must be prepared and submitted for approval by the Secretary. Authorization of appropriations is also included in the Act. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Such sums as necessary are authorized to carry out the Act, with $17,500,000 allocated for land acquisition within the Reserve.
